awd_titl_txt: RAPID/Collaborative Research: Liquefaction Mitigation of Silts using MIDP and Field Testing with NHERI UTexas Large Mobile Shakers
awd_abstract_narration:
The overall objective of this Grant for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project is to evaluate the potential for a soil liquefaction mitigation technique in relatively fine-grained soils. This technique uses new advancements in the field of bio-remediation and will be tested in the field at a site located in Portland, Oregon. The project addresses a major seismic problem in Oregon, where many infrastructure facilities are founded on non-plastic to low-plasticity silts that are susceptible to liquefaction in a Magnitude 9 Cascadia Subduction Zone earthquake. The site selected for study are near the Critical Energy Infrastructure (CEI) hub located in northwest Portland, where 90 percent of the Oregon's liquid fuel and all jet fuels for Portland's airport are handled. The seismic vulnerability of fuel tanks at the CEI hub is a critical impediment to Oregon's resilience and energy reliability in the wake of a major earthquake. If the mitigation method in this project is proved to be effective in the field, it will provide a vertical step for adopting this solution for infrastructure founded on liquefiable silty soils. This will enhance the resiliency of Oregon after a major earthquake, and it can be adopted in other places with similar subsurface conditions.

This project will evaluate the potential for microbially induced desaturation via dissimilatory reduction of nitrogen (denitrification) to mitigate liquefaction potential in relatively fine-grained soils. We hypothesize that 1) denitrification via two weeks of treatment can lower the degree of saturation to 80 percent in silty soils in the field, 2) this level of desaturation will eliminate pore water pressure generation in treated soils subjected to in-situ cyclic strains, and 3) the desaturation will persist for years due to the small pore size in silty soils (although this will need to be verified in subsequent research). Our approach to evaluate these hypotheses involves in-situ shaking using NHERI@UTexas field equipment at a site before and after treatment, and periodic monitoring of compression (P-) wave velocities during the next 3 to 5 years.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Field trials of microbially induced desaturation (MID) were conducted at two sites in Portland, Oregon underlain by liquefiable fine-grained soils. MID is an emerging method for mitigating the potential for triggering liquefaction. MID treatment stimulates native denitrifying microbes with a solution containing nitrate as well as other substrates and nutrients. A product of the denitrification reactions is nitrogen gas which displaces porewater and in turn reduces the in situ degree of saturation (Sr) of the soil. Since desaturated soils produce less excess porewater pressure than saturated soils during cyclic loading, MID can reduce the potential for triggering liquefaction. The objectives of the field trials were to evaluate the ability of MID treatment to reduce Sr of fine-grained liquefiable soils in a field setting, and investigate whether cyclic-induced excess porewater pressures are reduced due to MID treatment. MID treatment performance and associated subsurface changes in Sr were evaluated with field monitoring and sampling at the field sites. Field monitoring data included seismic wave velocities measured with crosshole and downhole techniques, embedded in situ sensors, and water chemistry measurements. Monitoring data were collected pre-treatment, during treatment, and post-treatment. Recovery and testing of soil samples was performed pre-treatment and post-treatment to measure changes in Sr. The results indicate liquefiable soil at both sites was successfully desaturated from Sr values greater than 99.5% pre-treatment to values ranging between 80% and 96% post-treatment. The results also indicate that the desaturation persisted for at least two years post-treatment. Additionally, the effectiveness of MID to reduce cyclically-induced porewater pressures was investigated at one site using mobile shaker trucks from NHERI@UTexas equipment before and after applying MID in the field. The reduction in cyclically-induced porewater pressures was not significant at smaller cyclic shear strains. While further studies are required to fill knowledge gaps regarding the effectiveness of MID as a liquefaction mitigation method for silt soils, this study showed that this method can be effectively used to desaturate fine-grained soils under field conditions.

The project addressed a major seismic problem in Pacific Northwest, where many infrastructure facilities are founded on non-plastic to low-plasticity silts that are susceptible to liquefaction in a Magnitude 9 Cascadia Subduction Zone earthquake. The two sites used in this study are located near critical infrastructure, including by the Portland International Airport and the Critical Energy Infrastructure (CEI) hub. The seismic vulnerability of above ground liquid fuel storage tanks and piping infrastructure at the CEI hub is a critical impediment to Oregon?s resilience and energy reliability in the wake of a major earthquake. The findings in this research highlight the potential to use MID as a non-intrusive liquefaction mitigation method, which will have broader impacts on improving resiliency in Portland and other areas around the world. A two-day workshop and field demonstration was organized in September 2019 in Portland with presentations from the research team members from Portland State University, Arizona State University, University of Texas at Austin, and industry partners from Condon Johnson & Associates to disseminate research findings and engage public. The workshop was attended by over 100 practitioners, contractors, public community, and media.

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2021
Modified by: Arash Khosravifar
